questions.question:
Question 1: A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory 
investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons: • History of OCP use • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

questions.question:
Question 2: A 40-year-old man with a history of bowel resection for Crohn's disease develops 
megaloblastic anaemia. Which component of the vitamin B12 metabolism is likely to be 
affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ileal resection for Crohn's disease can cause megaloblastic anaemia due to the decrease in cubilin 
receptors. They are the vitamin B12 receptors on the ileum. Absorption of vitamin B12 involves the following steps: • Pepsin in the stomach releases vitamin B12 from the binding proteins in the food • Released B12 binds to haptocorrin, which is a salivary protein • In the duodenum, pancreatic proteases release B12 from haptocorrin • B12 binds to intrinsic factor to form IF-B12 complex • In the ileum, ileal enterocytes that contain cubulin receptors (IF receptor) endocytose the 
complex • In the ileal cells, B12 is associated with transcobalamin II, which is a carrier protein • B12 is delivered to the liver, bone marrow and GIT 348 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: In which of the following patients would you not suspect megaloblastic anaemia caused by 
vitamin B12 deficiency?

options.a: A 5-year-old child with fish tapeworm infestation

questions.explanation:
Phenytoin therapy causes folate deficiency leading to megaloblastic anaemia. It does not cause 
vitamin B12 deficiency. Dietary folate is in polyglutamate form, which is then converted into monoglutamates by the 
intestinal conjugase. Phenytoin acts by inhibiting this enzyme, thereby causing folate deficiency, 
and thus megaloblastic anaemia. Options A, B and C: They cause megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiciency.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. The image of 
her hand is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Skin hyperpigmentation especially on the dorsum of hands involving the knuckles is seen in 
cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency which is a causative factor of megaloblastic anaemia. In megaloblastic anaemia, there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective 
hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large 
erythroid precursors and red cells. Clinical features of megaloblastic anaemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency) include: Peripheral smear findings: • Macro-ovalocytes • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but 
the MCHC is not elevated. • Reticulocyte count is low • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is 
severe 349 
Sold by @itachibot • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear 
hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophils seen in megaloblastic anaemia. System

questions.question:
Question 5: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given 
below? 341 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil are suggestive 
of megaloblastic anaemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a cause of megaloblastic anaemia. Peripheral smear findings in megaloblastic anaemia: • Macro-ovalocytes • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but 
the MCHC is not elevated. • Reticulocyte count is low • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is 
severe • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear 
hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in patients with megaloblastic 
anaemia?
questions.explanation:
The reticulocyte count is decreased in megaloblastic anaemia. The reticulocyte count is indicative of bone marrow function and its ability to produce healthy 
erythrocytes. In megaloblastic anemia, there is intramedullary hemolysis leading to raised indirect 
bilirubin and impaired erythroid maturation leading to a low reticulocyte count.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient is suspected to have megaloblastic anaemia. Which of the following will not be 
helpful in differentiating vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Increased serum homocysteine levels are common to both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate 
deficiency. Hence, it cannot be used to differentiate between them.

questions.question:
Question 8: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following 
finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.

options.d: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation

questions.explanation:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. 
They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is 
considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division. 351 
Sold by @itachibot Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions: • Megaloblastic anaemia • Post-splenectomy patients • Lead poisoning • Hemolytic anemias Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency. Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, 
thalassemia and sickle cell disease. Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

questions.question: Question 9: Schilling's test can be used for all the following except

options.a: To differentiate between vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
options.b: To identify the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
options.c: To identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia

questions.explanation: Schilling test cannot identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is false regarding the antibodies of pernicious anaemia?

options.a: Type I antibodies are found in both plasma and gastric juice
options.b: Type I antibody blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor
options.c: Type II antibodies prevent the binding of the IF-B12 complex to ileal receptors
options.d: Type III antibodies are against haptocorrin

questions.explanation:
Type III antibodies are not against haptocorrin. They recognize the  and  subunits of the gastric 
proton pumps. Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis. It 
impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut. Types of antibodies in pernicious anaemia are: • Type I antibodies - block the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. They are found in both 
plasma and gastric juice • Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 (IF-B12) complex to its 
ileal receptor • Type III antibodies - recognize the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump of parietal cells

questions.question:
Question 11: A 53-year-old woman presents with complaints of light-headedness every time she stands up. 
She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis on methotrexate. On examination, she has pallor 
and brittle nails. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.a: Serum iron and tissue iron levels are normal
options.b: Anemia can be normocytic and normochromic

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaemia of chronic diseases (ACD). In this condition, 
the anaemia initially can be normocytic normochromic. ACD occurs in the setting of persistent systemic inflammation. It is associated with • Low serum iron • Reduced total iron-binding capacity • Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages 352 
Sold by @itachibot Inflammatory mediators like IL-6 stimulate an increase in the production of hepcidin. 
This inhibits ferroportin function in the macrophages and reduces the transfer of iron from the 
storage pool to developing erythroid precursors in the marrow. As a result, erythroid precursors 
are starved for iron despite the availability of plenty of iron in tissue macrophages.

questions.question: Question 12: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.

options.a: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
options.b: Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
options.c: Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
options.d: Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.explanation:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by 
only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals. Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include: • Severe liver disease • Abetalipoproteinemia • Post splenectomy • Hyposplenism The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye. 353 
Sold by @itachibot Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by 
smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape 
and distribution compared to acanthocytes. Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include: • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia) • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion • Storage artefact The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the most common cause of aplastic anemia?
questions.explanation:
354 
Sold by @itachibot From the given options, the most common cause of aplastic anemia is drugs. Causes of aplastic anemia: Acquired • Idiopathic - most common cause (about 65% of the cases) • Acquired stem-cell defects • Immune-mediated Chemical agents • Dose-related • Alkylating agents • Antimetabolites • Benzene • Chloramphenicol • Inorganic arsenals • Idiosyncratic • Chloramphenicol • Phenylbutazone • Organic arsenicals • Carbamazepine • Penicillamine • Gold salts Physical agents • Whole-body irradiation • Viral infections - Hepatitis, CMV, EBV, VZ Inherited • Fanconi anemia • Telomerase defects

questions.question:
Question 14: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness and fatigue. Her hemogram is 
given below. What is the best investigation to arrive at the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given hemogram is suggestive of pancytopenia. Cause of pancytopenia can be aplastic 
anaemia (hypocellular bone marrow) or myeloid neoplasms (hypercellular bone marrow). Hence, 
the best investigation is bone marrow biopsy to differentiate between them. Findings in bone marrow biopsy in aplastic anaemia: • Markedly hypocellular bone marrow largely devoid of hematopoietic cells 355 
Sold by @itachibot • Abundant fat cells • Fibrous stroma, scattered lymphocytes, and plasma cells Bone marrow aspiration often yields a dry tap, so biopsy is preferred.

questions.question:
Question 15: Bone marrow biopsy of a patient with pancytopenia is given below. What is the most common 
infectious cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given bone marrow biopsy shows a hypocellular bone marrow with abundant fat cells which is 
suggestive of aplastic anaemia. In this condition, the most common infectious cause is viral 
hepatitis of the non-A, Non-B, Non-C, and Non-G type. The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow. Note- Viral hepatitis, parvovirus B19, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), cytomegalovirus and 
Epstein-Barr virus can cause aplastic anemia. Viral hepatitis is however the most common cause. 356 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is likely to develop in a patient with aplastic anaemia?
questions.explanation:
Aplastic anaemia can transform into both acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and myelodysplastic 
syndrome (MDS).

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following causes pure red cell aplasia?
questions.explanation: Causes of pure red cell aplasia include: • Neoplasms - thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia • Drug exposure - phenytoin, azathioprine and isoniazid • Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin • Parvovirus infection • Hereditary - Diamond Blackfan syndrome

questions.question: Question 18: What is the most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and 
prostate. Myelophthisic anaemia describes a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions 
replace normal marrow elements. Causes include: • Metastatic cancer • Granulomatous diseases • Myeloproliferative neoplasms. This leads to the release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms into 
peripheral blood (leukoerythroblastosis) and tear-drop shaped red cells. The image given below shows a peripheral smear with teardrop cells. 357 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive weakness and chronic fatigue. Physical 
examination reveals a hard nodule of about 1cm in the prostate. His lab reports reveal low Hb 
and elevated PSA. Peripheral blood smear shows a normocytic normochromic picture. There 
are some occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop cells and 2 nucleated RBCs per 100 white 346 
Sold by @itachibot cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myelophthisic anaemia. Prostatic mass with elevated 
PSA and age suggestive of prostatic carcinoma, which could be the likely cause in this case. It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. 
The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. Lab findings of myelophthisic anaemia include: • Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image • Presence of tear-drop cells

questions.question:
Question 20: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 
A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an 
endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen this 
patient?

options.c: They are larger in size than red cell

questions.explanation:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis 
and vitamin B12 deficiency. Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented 
neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic 
acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia. Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies 
which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake 
of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of 
each of these include: • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF). • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors. 358 
Sold by @itachibot • Autoantibody type III acts against the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump, which 
impairs the production of intrinsic factor. These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, 
infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells. 359 
Sold by @itachibot Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis
